title.en-GB: Photine - Smarter Digital Photo Frames

excerpt.en-GB: Photine is a range of smarter digital photo frames I developed from 2013 to mid 2014 for my startup Nine Studios. Resulting in a spectacular failure of a crowdfunding campaign. Read more to see the video and funky fresh images.

content.en-GB:
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/sgWO0wx8n34" width="600" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

## Key Facts:

*   Built a series of the first ever multiple screen digital photo frames
*   Spent a year and a half on this project
*   Raised 2 rounds of finance to pay for the development
*   Won 2 competitions and shortlisted in 3 for this project
*   Ran a unsuccessful [crowdfunding campaign](https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/photine-smarter-better-connected-digital-photo-frames#/) but raised £4366
*   Built working models which look amazing
*   Created an awesome [pitch video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sgWO0wx8n34) showing them off

![Photine digital photo frames overview image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3K5DaV0Qfu226cSWaGCOUi/52347c50b81911671182dd59d93a245a/photine-digital-photo-frames-overview.png) From 2013 into mid 2014 I was working on my startup Nine Studios developing smart home products. Our main product was Photine, a range of smarter digital photo frames. The problem here was that people love photos and over 90% of people display photos in some way  at home. However existing digital photo frames are perceived as ugly, a pain to update and lack in variety and creativity. Our idea was to create the first ever multiple screen digital photo frames, that are wifi enabled to gather your latest photos automatically, and have advanced smart features. The project resulted in us creating a series of 3 separate digital photo frames models. A 1 screen, 3 screen and 4 screen. The multiple screen devices were instantly unique for their collage like layout and beautiful wooden design. ![Photine digital photo frames design image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/6LXj25HFdYc4u2cqwwy2OC/59b99094f5d46323f341ae131c2cb21c/photine-digital-photo-frames-design.png) The frames could connect to your photos on Facebook, google drive, Dropbox and from your local computer and would automatically figure out which photos to show based on like count, who's tagged in the photos, dates, locations etc. So the user doesn't have to tediously pick albums to display. The smart features included:

*   Whose at home: let the frames know who is coming over, so it will pick pictures where there people are tagged in them
*   Push to frame: Push a photo from your mobile device directly to the frame
*   Smart selection: Photine automatically displays photos for you based of their popularity, location and the people in the photos.

During the project we raised over 5 thousand pounds in finance, won 2 competitions and shortlisted for 3 more and ran an unsuccessful [crowdfunding campaign](https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/photine-smarter-better-connected-digital-photo-frames#/) that taught us more than anything. ![Photine digital photo frames with app image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5ic2RV73nG0sYaQmMgKiyS/6b182c7e41ae00b12a09b5b25eae2508/photine-digital-photo-frames-app.png)

title.en-GB: TedX UCL Talk - Designing Future Homes

excerpt.en-GB: Our homes are changing. Connected products and advancements in technology are bringing in a new era of adaptive and smart products into our homes. The ramifications of these trends have an important impact on how we will want to design and innovate these new generation of products.

content.en-GB:
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MCKvbFDGSIQ" width="600" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

## Key Facts:

*   [TedX talk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCKvbFDGSIQ) I gave in 2013 about my research on the future of home design and open business models for smart home products

## Talk Description:

Our homes are changing. Connected products and advancements in technology are bringing in a new era of adaptive and smart products into our homes. The ramifications of these trends have an important impact on how we will want to design and innovate these new generation of products. Software has been excellent at letting us personalise devices, but when these current and future trends start really transforming the home will we want the same level of personalisation in our hardware products?

## Profile Description:

Charlie is an engineering graduate in product design and manufacture. He has written a paper on the future of home design and has been exploring his own design startup for the last 3 years. Since being at UCL, studying an MSc in Technology Entrepreneurship, he has become more involved in the internet of things scene in London. Charlie has previously designed a range of wifi colour changing lights and is currently redesigning the digital photo frame for his company Nine Studios Ltd.

title.en-GB: GitHack - Open Source Git Client

content.en-GB:

title.en-GB: Charlie Jackson Website

excerpt.en-GB: My personal website, that shows what I'm currently doing and all my past projects. Currently built in Wordpress with my own custom theme.

content.en-GB:
## Key Facts:

*   Been building and iterating the site since 2010
*   Built in Wordpress with my own custom theme
*   The current design is very simplistic and minimalist
*   Shows what I am doing now and my past projects
*   Uses: Wordpress, PHP, Javascript, SASS, npm, gulp, browserify, Docker, Jenkins, MySQL, git
*   Check out the code on [Github](https://github.com/cajacko/charlie-jackson-website)

The latest version of my site was built in 2 weeks at the start of January, to document all the projects I have worked on and to let people know what I am currently up to. The site is heavily influenced by Derek Sivers, whose site is also very simplistic and focuses on the content. The reason behind this was for me to concentrate on my projects and not the development of the site itself. As a web developer, if I had a fancy site, I would end up spending months trying to perfect it and never write any content. Choosing what not to do is usually the harder but more necessary step to take. ![Charlie Jacksons website screenshot](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/10NlBRNHJsIGUeqsGC42Ec/7d1b8b596d27ddc7383ffde0e66f85e5/charlie-jackson-website-2017.jpg)

title.en-GB: Social Helper

excerpt.en-GB: Social Helper is a tool that automates your social media profiles. Currently Social Helper can automatically retweet popular and recent items based off a set of Twitter search queries and a set of blacklisted queries.

content.en-GB:
![Twwitter Screenshot](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/Fni1JIKjUQguGIQ4uI0kK/bce4b9939a71e44016c080e4c3cea079/twitter.png) Social Helper is a tool that automates your social media profiles. Currently Social Helper can automatically retweet popular and recent items based off a set of Twitter search queries and a set of blacklisted queries. If you'd like to use it yourself follow the installation instructions on the Github Repo found [here](https://github.com/cajacko/social-helper). I am currently using this to automate my personal Twitter account [@charliejackson](https://twitter.com/charliejackson). Social Helper is built with the following technologies:

*   The front end is built with React JS and Redux, compiled using webpack
*   The front end is served with a NodeJS server using Express JS
*   The backend is a basic PHP API
*   Uses a standard MySQL database
*   Docker is used to containerise the database, api and web parts, this also makes it super easy to deploy

![Social Helper Screenshot](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1iLPDjurusm2WS06cI6SMK/4e0193c78236e549dcd3fb05faf7f24c/social-helper-screenshot.png) Here is the brief I gave myself on the 16th of January 2016:

* * *

Social helper is my current project that I am working on until the 30th of January 2017\. It is a tool that automates your social media profiles, as I am useless and keeping up with posting. I'm working on this for 2 weeks and have a few goals I need to achieve and some stretch goals that would be nice if I have enough time.

## Critical Goals:

*   Create a service that automatically retweets the most popular tweets given a twitter search query
*   The time a tweet should get sent out is based on a user specified cron
*   Multiple user accounts should be able to use the service
*   Multiple search queries should be given for one account, and be evenly tweeted about
*   The service should make sure it doesn't tweet the same thing, or tweet too much from the same user

## Stretch Goals

*   The service should be managed through a web interface
*   The service should track the amount of followers on the Twitter account every day, so it can measure effectiveness of posting
*   Each Twitter user should get a weekly performance report so they can adjust their settings

The current work I am doing on this project is part of a bigger idea that I may come back to from time to time. The bigger idea would be a more developed service including features like:

*   Integrating with your website to suggest or automatically share old and new content
*   Connecting to your personal photos, scanning through them, and suggesting things to put on Instagram/Pinterest
    *   Also a service that does this by looking through your project folders
*   Finding and suggesting conversations you should interact with on Twitter in real time
*   Automatically adjusting what to Tweet/Retweet based on the performance of past tweets

title.en-GB: Lumine - Range of Smart Wifi Lights

excerpt.en-GB: Lumine is a range of four wi-fi, contemporary and colour changing lights, designed for my startup, Nine Studios. I designed these during my last year studying Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham.

content.en-GB:
![Lumine overview image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3b0iszDBzOOuIGkigKkOYQ/9964315f0cf1eadaa1631b4090c0cc70/lumine-overview.jpg) Lumine is a range of four wi-fi, contemporary and colour changing lights, designed for my startup, Nine Studios. I designed these during my last year studying [Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham](http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/ugstudy/courses/mechanicalmaterialsandmanufacturingengineering/beng-product-design-manufacture.aspx). The range includes a pendant, wall, floor and table light designed with a common dome aesthetic and matching chrome plated finishes. The products can all be controlled by usual ways, either your existing wired switches for the pendant and wall light or the built in switches on the floor and table light. However they can join your existing wi-fi network and can then allow a whole host of new features:

*   Control all aspects of the lights from your smart phone, tablet or computer.
*   Apply one change and all the lights in a room or even the whole house can change at the same time.
*   Control includes:
    *   On/off
    *   Brightness
    *   Colour
    *   Moving patterns (e.g. Switching colours over time, pulsating etc.)
*   Set up automated features which are controlled and processed by cloud computing (on remote servers across the internet):
    *   To change depending on the time of day (could turn on in the evening, gradually get brighter throughout the day etc.)
    *   Be less bright when turned on late at night (especially useful if going to the bathroom at night)
*   Learn about you:
    *   Your daily lighting routines can be recorded so that if you go on holiday you can set the lights to turn on and off as if you were at home.
    *   Saves your commonly used colours, moods and theme settings for easy recollection.
*   New features are available instantly over the internet

![Lumine explainer image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/6z3aFyDWBGIIUO6GccqUgq/393247593fdcb5a3086334acd64982ba/lumine-explainer-image.jpg) The products utilise an RGB LED screw fit bulb which offers long life and low energy usage. The products work normally as soon as they are plugged in or wired. To connect them to the network you have to install the relevant app for the smartphone, tablet or computer or you could just visit the specified IP address in any internet browser on the network. Within the app it can scan for available devices and assign them to the specific rooms. If there are problems the lights can be reset and disconnected from the network by locating and holding down the reset switch, found on each light, for 5 seconds, this will then cause the lights to flash. One of the main benefits of the products is that they still work on their own or more can be added to the network to greatly improve the experience.

## System of Integration

Further concepts in the product offering which were briefly developed include a touch screen control panel, a SMART hub and a wi-fi RGB LED bulb.

### Control Panel

The control panel can be retro fit instead of the existing wall switches and offers all the functions as the control app but from the convenience of where your existing switches were. It includes several physical switches for intuitive on/off control. Especially for guests. The inclusion of a proximity sensor means the screen only turns on when something is moving close to it. The control panel also has a camera and microphone which can be used to add further automated features to the system:

*   Turn on/off the lights with movement around the house.
*   Control through voice
*   Could change colours and moods in reaction to sounds or movement.

### SMART Hub

The SMART hub can act as it’s own wi-fi router of join an existing network. It can then do all the processing instead of the could computing. Resulting in automated features even if the internet is offline. It also has a built in hard drive for backing up computers wirelessly.

### RGB wifi LED Bulb

The RGB wifi LED bulb allows you to connect your existing lights to the network. Just use this bulb instead, set it up though the app and all the SMART features are available. This bulb would be very expensive and due to the need to replace bulbs, even though LED’s last a long time, it is not as sustainable a solution as the connectivity being in the fixings. ![Lumine Buble pendant light](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/64KL3GIxxei0uoMwuUY4Ce/eaf19efd8e564ca6c3aa1192b38733eb/lumine-buble.jpg)

### The Wider Context

The technology used in the lights could be licensed to other designers and manufacturers in order to create more affordable lights in many different styles. The fittings themselves could be sold to use with existing shades or wi-fi power adapters could be plugged into existing lights to add connectivity. Being wi-fi connected lights these products have the potential of communicating with other SMART devices around the home. These includes:

*   Linking with a SMART TV in order to react to certain events (e.g. Become dimmer when a film is playing)
*   Connect with a music system (e.g. When playing music through iTunes the lights could react and pulsate to the type of music if you want.)
*   Connect to the doorbell. This could have huge benefits for deaf people as the lights could flash when the doorbell rings. Also if speakers are connected to the same system they could fade down the music and play the doorbell sound.
*   React to the fire alarm. The lights could flash if the alarm goes off.
*   Separate sensor units could be purchased to place throughout the house as desired and be utilised by the lights to turn on before someone enters a room and to automatically turn off where no one is.

### Related Product Ideas for the Company

*   Standard fittings for other manufactures to easily utilise in their designs.
*   Standard fittings for consumers to connect existing lighting.
*   Wi-fi power adapters/sockets.
*   Further lighting ranges.
*   Connected speakers, fire alarms, doorbells, TV’s, security cameras, blinds, kitchen appliances and utility management.
*   Sensor units for the home, to give data to the appliances.

title.en-GB: Remember When - Micro Journaling Platform

excerpt.en-GB: Remember When makes it easier to keep a journal of the amazing things that happen in your life. It is a micro journal that has been available as a website and mobile app. This is a project I build for my startup Nine Studios.

content.en-GB:
![Remember When Screenshot](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2iUl0mUL4gayKC2EU4S2yS/c7657cab7deab4209559c029b8c62d7c/remember-when.jpg) Key Facts:

*   Micro journaling platform
*   Find the repo [here](https://github.com/cajacko/RememberWhen) on GitHub

Keeping a diary of the weird and wonderful stuff you do can be a ball ache. It’s great to have a record of these events, like pictures, something you can look back at an be like “Holy shit, I forgot that I wrestled a bear in Angola”. However writing these long entries can be irritating and the big blocks of text aren’t the most inspiring things to look at. Enter Remember When, the micro journaling platform that I have developed to make it easier to record and relive the best moments in your life. Remember When has gone through being a website and more recently a mobile app for iOS and Android, built with React Native.

title.en-GB: e-Lectronic Notepad - A Smart e-Paper Notebook

excerpt.en-GB: An electronic notebook that has multiple e-paper pages that you can remove and draw on. This was a project I worked on whilst studying Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottinhgam.

content.en-GB: ![e-Lectronic Notepad](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1NqXemVEIguoAGggiMO8y0/0a5313e1a288724189a5aa6079e2b3a5/e-lectronic-notepad.jpg) This was the first university project in which I was not asked to redesign an existing product and instead had a much more open brief – to explore tomorrow’s workplace. With this in mind I set upon looking at why the paperless office never came about. The final design is a notebook that consists of 2 high resolution touch screens that are hinged together and a separate set of colour e-ink pages which can magnetically attach to the main notepad. This product gives you some of the main benefits that working with paper does, like spreading out pages so you can quickly reference multiple documents, whilst adding in the best of technology, such as continuous file/note saving and sharing work across the internet. Truly helping to bring about that fabled paperless office. What I really enjoyed about this project was how my user research became more about observational work rather than focus groups or interviews. I spent hours in offices, libraries and classrooms observing the different ways people use paper and occasional asking why someone would do something in a certain way. As the project was titled Tomorrow’s Workplace this is a near future concept and hopefully we might see similar products appear in the next few years as developments with colour e-ink displays become cheaper and more widespread.

title.en-GB: Global Commands - NPM Module to run commonly used commands

excerpt.en-GB: Run commands from any directory. Tired of changing directory all the time in the terminal? Add all your frequent commands into a .globalCommands file on your desktop and run them from within any directory.

content.en-GB:
## ![Global commands image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/Llaabd64I88gCkie0CKue/9d934d2e89514d34e29343f7e9fc7c09/global-commands.png)

## Key Facts

*   NPM module for running commonly used commands
*   Run these commands from any directory
*   Setup via a config file on your desktop
*   See the repo [here](https://github.com/cajacko/global-commands) on GitHub.

Run commands from any directory. Tired of changing directory all the time in the terminal? Add all your frequent commands into a .globalCommands file on your desktop and run them from within any directory. This package runs in Node.js, so get download the latest version and install this package with: `npm install -g global-commands` Now you can setup your frequent commands file. Add a file named .globalCommands to your desktop and base it off the following: `{` `"test": "echo 'global command'",` `"startMyProject": {` `"directory": "/Users/username/Documents/Code/Projects/myProject",` `"command": "npm start"` `}` `}` The file must be a valid JSON object. Each entry must be the command name followed be either: The command or An object specifying the directory to run the command from, and the command itself. You can now run the commands using: `globCom test` `globCom startMyProject` etc.

title.en-GB: Reading Room - Working as a UX Developer

excerpt.en-GB: Reading Room is one of the UK's top digital agencies which I joined in October 2015\. My work mainly involves front end development and working closely with the designers and back end devs to ensure that end users will get a site that looks great, responds well, is highly accessible and technically works well with the back end systems.

content.en-GB:
![Reading Room Logo](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2ey65BzppuiS0K0gKwSC2M/2603bd91b7e833163428f87177d455bf/reading-room-logo.png)

## Key Facts

*   Web development agency based in London with around 100 people
*   Been working as a UX Developer since October 2015
*   Working with React JS, Node JS, Javascript, JQuery, Sass, PostCSS, Git and all the basic front end tech
*   All projects are built in PHP or .net
*   Worked with test frameworks such as Cucumber, Mocha and Chai
*   Have played a lot of pool and table tennis :)

[Reading Room](https://www.readingroom.com/) is one of the UK's top digital agencies which I joined in October 2015\. My work mainly involves front end development and working closely with the designers and back end devs to ensure that end users will get a site that looks great, responds well, is highly accessible and technically works well with the back end systems. I have worked on dozens of different projects, ranging from large enterprise clients with millions of visitors to county police sites who need excellent accessibility and clarity with their user journeys. Some of most enjoyable work has been with pushing more modern front end development frameworks such as React JS and integrating a lot of functional testing with Cucumber JS. All our projects are built in PHP or .net with CMS's such as Drupal, Kentico, Sitecore and Umbraco. As an experienced PHP developer I have contributed to bits of PHP to those projects where necessary and often build prototype sites in PHP. Working on the .net projects have also given me a great appreciation of how to shape the front end differently for the particular quirks of each platform. I have also developed greatly as a pool and table tennis player and my posture has greatly improved whilst using a giant exercise ball as my chair.

title.en-GB: Multi Commands - NPM module to run multiple commands in separate windows

excerpt.en-GB: NPM module for running multiple commands in separate windows.

content.en-GB:
## ![Multi Commands screenshot](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2oK7CRoEDqWwwKaiuoeKmm/1bdce7086b4ca7258a92c7b99a336fe5/multi-commands.png)

## Key Facts:

*   NPM module for running multiple commands in separate windows
*   Useful for easily running multiple watch commands whilst developing
*   e.g. Running a Node Server with Nodemon and developing the front end with a gulp watch task
*   Works on Windows and Mac OS
*   See the repo [here](https://github.com/cajacko/multi-commands) on GitHub

Install with `npm install multi-commands --save-dev` Or install globally with `npm install -g multi-commands` You can then run multiple commands using the multi command and enclosing your commands with double quotes: `multi "webpack --progress --colors --watch" "nodemon server.js --exec babel-node"`

title.en-GB: Wedding - I Got Married!

excerpt.en-GB: That time me and Viki planned our wedding and got married! Lots of decoration, lots of fun and some amazing photos/videos.

content.en-GB:
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Pusi3fGnMlw" width="600" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

## Key Facts:

*   Got married to the amazing [Viki Bell](https://vikibell.com)
*   On the 18th of July 2015
*   Had the ceremony in [Glemham Hall](http://www.glemhamhall.co.uk/), reception at my parents place in Thorpeness, Suffolk
*   We did all the planning and decoration ourselves with the fantastic help of our friends and family

After the proposal and weeks of being taken out for champagne, we got into full wedding planning mode. Having done a design degree and Viki an art degree we wanted to do a lot of the planning and decoration ourselves. Having the reception at my parents place in Suffolk was the clear choice, there was enough space for a big marquee and the surrounding buildings look fucking awesome. We liked the idea of hosting it in a marquee as it would act as a blank canvas for us to do what we wanted inside it. With that sorted we started looking for ceremony venues around Thorpeness and as soon as we found Glemham Hall it became the obvious solution. An impressive old mansion house with amazing grounds and a grass tennis court for me and the groomsmen to play on in the morning. We decided to design the invites ourselves. Viki drew both Glemham Hall and my parents house, I then took these and digitized them, adding shading and tidying them up on Photoshop. Making the seating plan was some of the most fun we had (apart from the wedding day I guess). We got a large board, some paint, speakers and a crate of Corona, went out into the woods and proceeded to get very messy and drunk in the sunshine making a crazy paint mess on the board. The day before the wedding we then overlaid the table plan. Inside the marquee we used 2 kilometres of different coloured ribbon and strung it up from the center to the sides. Taking absolutely ages, but totally worth it in the end. Now we have loads of left over ribbon if you need to borrow some? Read more about the wedding on Viki's [blog post](https://vikibell.com/posts/wedding-day-part-i/). ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3eeJqSZB1YkOaUcC8Q6OeS/f45ce2e667c5b4c241bd6cf868bb1067/wedding-tennis.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1yCmJvaHhymqIgAKAWqK4/9598f7a9967cb0403347c40c0d4954cc/wedding-viki-morning.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3ULzln51fqaAOIEEequ0gu/b5af5b92bb3b5b5cbfc51502e2dc8ac5/wedding-glemham-hall-interior.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/73Fb88sZ7USy4E6CSGOYKE/31af31bca76f8bd5cd4bf31d7587de80/wedding-campervan.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3XIi5dXxQ4KOueUo0UasyS/709d5542e48e272fa988ee678c8d58e7/wedding-invite.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/lr6hjyhnnqUQcQIsaYGQE/e228749f88fd7f9375d9417c76613870/wedding-glemham-hall-exterior.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4Ln4ZK8Wi4cUaEWWg8OMk0/5bd51f3123fc6a6232b428db2ef37a15/wedding-viki-aston.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5oDZtPWU5aU8Y6oekWkg0U/05187b90dfa96b802c698626960540c9/wedding-ceremony-laugh.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2tSDnTwzO0KUSEgCKasosE/af14d7113a42c3562606b22da26b860b/wedding-landrover.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5He29hLb8sicIc6OSO8kMS/fd31fa6288c73bab39df2ebfe682e7fc/wedding-marquee.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/pmB6L7uGD6II60SoE6wQ8/2d024b4ab32724959fec768378885df7/wedding-table-plan.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/r93vpTyqOWecaeSq8IkQE/40bd83b5d9cea37780dc86d4e7f1cea9/wedding-shellpits.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3blWl4pkoggaMWyCMg4C2g/0524bab5cad67c58df479b67b7e634b0/wedding-viki-spin.jpg) ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/6vSjSJY1CEk6E862KqEicw/9eec1a3ba3979baae54aa3fa5ea310f9/wedding-dance.jpg)

title.en-GB: Nine Studios - My Tech Startup

excerpt.en-GB: Nine Studios is my tech startup that I founded whilst in university 2010\. Over the years it's gone through a number of iterations, from design consultancy, tech store to building our own smart home products. We've raised finance, done a crowdfunding campaign, been a team of 9 people and pitched/presented at dozens of events. Nine Studios is currently on break, after running out of money... again.

content.en-GB: ![Nine Studios Team](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4xnt2iAGEouAkkiCu42eAa/e9a5959f861953c42be7194a2d9ad309/nine-studios-team.png) Nine Studios is my tech startup that I founded whilst in university 2010\. Over the years it's gone through a number of iterations, from design consultancy, tech store to building our own smart home products. We've raised finance, done a crowdfunding campaign, been a team of 9 people and pitched/presented at dozens of events. Nine Studios is currently on break, after running out of money... again. ## Here's a quick history so far: * Sept 2010 – I founded Nine Studios because I wanted a place where I could further develop the weird and wonderful ideas that come to me. * Oct 2010 – Nine Studios is running as a small design consultancy and performs one job, building the graphics and illustrations for the [Rainbow Training website](http://www.rainbowtraining.co.uk/). * Jan 2012 – Whilst in my final year studying a BEng in Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham I designed [Lumine](https://charliejackson.com/lumine/) for Nine Studios, a range of smart colour changing lights. * Summer 2012 – After graduating I realised I knew bugger all about running a company and decided to pursue a MSc in Technology Entrepreneurship at UCL. A fantastic course where you run your startup as you learn more about what you’re doing. At this point the idea was for Nine Studios to be a weird sort of design ecosystem made up of the following: * Nine Designs – A design consultancy where our employees could get exposed to a wide range of different projects, gaining new experiences in different industries. * Nine – Our in house design team where we build consumer friendly smart home products. * Nine Store – Our store where we sell great home design with a focus on smart home technology. Selling both our own products and those from other manufacturers. * Sept 2012 – Jan 2013  – It quickly became apparent that this model was way too ambitious to start it all at once, so we dialled it down to just Nine Store. We developed this business idea, closely following the Lean Startup methodology, lots of consumer interviews and the building of Minimal Viable Products (MVP’s). * Jan 2013 – At this point having been heavily involved in business development and e-commerce, I begun really missing the excitement of designing new and interesting products. The company pivoted, instead of selling consumer friendly smart home products, we were to build them. The problem we tackled was: * Digital photo frames are shit, they all look the same and are a ball ache to setup and keep new photos on them. There must be a better way of reliving the best moments in your life. * Jan 2013 – May 2013 – After performing extensive product, customer and business development we had developed [Photine](https://charliejackson.com/photine/), a family of smarter, better digital photo frames. We also had a team of six people working on making this happen, and had a lot of fun building all sorts of prototypes. * Summer 2013 – We won the London Entrepreneurs Challenge, the UCL Bright Ideas Award and got shortlisted for the Shell LiveWIRE Grand Ideas award and the NACUE Varsity Pitch Competition. We got a small amount of seed funding and started building towards a crowdfunding campaign to validate the market and raise the money we needed for manufacture. * Nov 2013 – We had put together a great looking crowdfunding campaign and launched on [Indiegogo](https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/photine-smarter-better-connected-digital-photo-frames). Unfortunately we failed spectacularly. However we learnt so much from the experience and I’m sure we’ll fuck up in a different way next time we crowdfund. * Dec 2013 – Feb 2015 – Nine Studios went through a hiatus, where we didn’t know what to do anymore, so we all went our separate ways for a while. * Feb 2015 – With my interest in futurology and mapping trends I built an online timeline tool called Nineline, as a Nine Studios venture, aimed at being a small tool for mapping trends, rather than a main focus for the company. * March 2015 – Nine Studios starts a reboot, focussing on building products and tools that make people happier. Our first such product, [Remember When](http://rememberwhen.life/), a micro journaling platform aiming to help you record and relive the best moments in your life. * October 2015 - Back in dormant mode again due to lack of money, but plans are still in play and waiting the right moment to come back again. * 2050 – …Great success, we’ve made the world a happier place and we’re working from our own private island, sipping cocktails and coming up with ridiculous ideas we can now afford to implement.

title.en-GB: Kitchen Block - A Modern Day Hostess Trolley

excerpt.en-GB: Whilst studying product design at Nottingham I was tasked with redesigning a domestic hostess trolley. The solution is a portable kitchen block for you to prepare food on, and maintain it's temperature in an insulated section.

content.en-GB: ![Hostess Trolley Overview](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1vhAJ50kmM8aUgsCMIS20y/f07fed9dc633480dddaefecf3dc0e685/hostess-trolley-overview.jpg) This was an interesting university project as I was tasked with finding out why domestic hostess trolleys went out of fashion and to design a new one for the modern consumer. I often had issues when asked to redesign a product, as I prefer to think about the root problem and new or better ways to solve it rather than being asked to improve an existing solution. However with regards to hostess trolleys I found that problems still existed when you have people over for food; you can often run out of preparation space, quite often you want to keep more drinks cold than you have space in the fridge and there can still be the problem of needing somewhere to keep some dishes/food warm. So my solution is a portable kitchen block that has a top surface you can prepare food on, a lower surface for temporarily placing utensils, and an insulated compartment for keeping food/drink warm or cold for longer. This is a design whose chopping surface now makes it a product to use everyday rather than the rarely used traditional hostess trolleys. With this project we were also told we could not use our 3D modelling software or rendering package so these visuals were done using Photoshop and Illustrator.

title.en-GB: Nineline - Timeline to Help You Track Trends and Predictions

excerpt.en-GB: See whats happened in the past and what's likely to happen in the future to inform your business development. Nineline is an online timeline where you can add trends, predictions and past events.

content.en-GB: ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5JUbPYfCb6K24cAo8U4YqW/56db34b4e564f8a126e69f6003274046/nineline.jpg) Check out the repo [here](https://github.com/cajacko/Nineline) on GitHub. Nineline is an online timeline that helps you track trends and predictions. The idea was heavily inspired the work of Richard Watson and the timelines he created during his futurology research. When doing my BEng in product design and manufacture, my dissertation was on the future of home design. I read a lot of futurist literature and created a giant pinboard to track trends and predictions. This is the digitisation of this pin board. Nineline is a WordPress based website that uses jQuery to position elements across the canvas. The current incarnation uses the Bootstrap framework, which made it much easier to get a decent looking site up and running quickly. The goal of Nineline is to help people plan ahead with their own products and businesses, to see what changes may be occurring and how to act accordingly. On the site I aim to allow people to add in their own predictions, track topics that interest them and engage with interesting predictions or articles.

title.en-GB: Mobile Market Stall - Product Design Group Project at Uni

excerpt.en-GB: This was my first full group design project studying Product Design, to design a mobile market stall, exciting stuff.

content.en-GB: ![Mobile Market Stall](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3vAh5kP7ZeOSMgGicCycwM/ebf74ef06dd02570131fbf19cea925a5/mobile-market-stall.jpg) This was my first full group design project, to design a mobile market stall. We created a design that enhances the look of traditional market stalls whilst offering improved flexibility, set up and portability. I was incredibly interested to see how working as a group would play out and had some amazing experiences, both negative and positive. I thoroughly enjoyed the way other people come up with such different concepts which in turn inspire your own thinking in different ways. An invaluable benefit of group work. On the other side it was interesting to handle dominant personalities and find ways to get everyone’s ideas heard and the most promising concepts pushed forward. I performed all the 3D renders and Photoshop work shown here for this project and I think it is an excellent example of my ability to create in context renders and images.

title.en-GB: Nottingham City Bus Shelter

excerpt.en-GB: My first design project whilst studying Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham.

content.en-GB: ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/GtXXtDIBaemSYQuk8OioM/cdfd1d298469ead6d4914594e46abfa2/bus-shelter-overview.jpg) This was my first design project whilst studying product design and was my first chance to really explore the design process. I was tasked with redesigning a bus shelter. I’ve always known that the best solutions come from a great understanding of the problem and people’s behaviours so I sucked up the courage to go out and figure out the buses in a new city, always a daunting task. I ended up spending days riding the bus, getting off at stops, observing what people were doing and asking various questions and opinions. The problems mainly came down to a lack of space and grubby or ugly designs. I therefore took it upon myself that Nottingham really needed a new striking design referencing some of the architectural beauties around the city, with a modular construction so that various layouts could be built for more or less popular locations. I always like including this initial project in my portfolio as it reminds me of the satisfaction and pleasure I took out of completing my first design project as a university student. I also think it is an interesting example of my own design style, I’m a particular fan of offset angles and the contrast of introducing curves, as seen in this design.

title.en-GB: How the potential changes in technology and the resultant impact on society will affect the design of home products in the next 8 years.

excerpt.en-GB: This was my dissertation whilst studying a BEng in Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham. This report analyses how home products have changed from 1900 - 2012 and uses this analysis, combined with futurologist literature, to present and explain four important trends which will affect home products from 2012 to 2020.

content.en-GB:
![Charlie Jackson Dissertation](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/54t4OvwEPm4WkeAO2YcY0C/6c9cff389d8ffdb59141693d958baeba/charlie-jackson-dissertation.jpg) This was my dissertation whilst studying a BEng in Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham. View the PDF [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BysuYQGa65FDa1B0LUE0aXN4X00/view?usp=sharing). This report analyses how home products have changed from 1900 - 2012 and uses this analysis, combined with futurologist literature, to present and explain four important trends which will affect home products from 2012 to 2020\. The report follows the effects of mass production, wars, social responsibility and technology on design as well as how these affect and initiated the design movements, such as modernism and post modernism. It is shown that the four defining trends are:

*   A physical digital world.
*   Personalisation.
*   The connected home.
*   Adaptive technology.

With these trends a future scenario is proposed in which trends and fashions are short lived, self expression in the home becomes more popular and home products become more connected to the internet and begin to be more adaptive to human lifestyles. Some example future products are described including a larger and more important role of the internet enabled television, SMART home lighting and domestic 3D printers. The accuracies and inaccuracies of the report are mentioned, including a possible need for a more extensive report and the effectiveness of historical analysis. This report aims to help inform the readers thoughts about emerging home trends so that they are more informed for the development and creation of their own projects.

title.en-GB: UCL - MSc in Technology Entrepreneurship at The University College London

excerpt.en-GB: In September 2012 I begun a masters degree in Technology Entrepreneurship at UCL. The degree is a hands on way of teaching you about creating, developing and growing a technology startup. The course encourages you to come with or create a startup and apply everything you learn throughout the course to that startup.

content.en-GB:
![Charlie Jackson UCL Presentation](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4UGskDVJ162ssS4UcoGYIg/8c0b92610fcccac50e49351dfa79c19e/charlie-jackson-ucl.jpg) In September 2012 I begun a masters degree in Technology Entrepreneurship at UCL. The degree is a hands on way of teaching you about creating, developing and growing a technology startup. The course encourages you to come with or create a startup and apply everything you learn throughout the course to that startup. Throughout the course we had modules in the areas of:

*   Entrepreneurial finance
*   Customer development
*   Business development
*   Creativity within organisations
*   Strategy for high growth companies
*   Marketing and analytics

Some of the main things I learnt was to do with the Lean Startup methodology and the idea of constantly testing your ideas. The term MVP (Minimal Viable Product) gets thrown around a lot, but the principle of creating a small test of any idea is a great way to learn. "Fail fast, fail often" was another term that was used and debated a lot during the course. The networking though was one of the best things about the course. Being based in London, which is such a fantastic tech and startup hub, our tutors showed us all of the meetups, competitions and hang outs that the capital has to offer. They were able to introduce us to dozens of investors and influencers in the scene, whilst the events UCL itself hosted expanded our networks even further. During my time at UCL I joined the UCL Enterprise society as a Graphic Designer and very often as the guy who pitches our events and programmes to the rest of UCL. When I joined the course my startup, [Nine Studios](https://charliejackson.com/nine-studios-my-tech-startup/), was looking at designing and selling smart home products, whilst consulting in product design at the same time. Clearly I was in need of this degree, as all I had were strange dreams in my head of what I wanted it to be. During the course I would end up pivoting my focus from selling smart home products to eventually designing and building our own range of digital photo frames. During the course my startup ended up with:

*   Winning the London Entrepreneurs Challenge
*   Winning the Bright Ideas Award
*   Shortlisted in the top 6 for Britains Top Real Role Model
*   Shortlisted for the Shell LiveWIRE Grand Ideas Award
*   Shortlisted for the NACUE Varsity Pitch Competition

I also gave a [TEDx talk](https://charliejackson.com/tedx/) during TEDxUCL on the future of home design, which was my major research area on my undergraduate degree. At the end of the degree I ended up with a great startup that I would continue developing and achieved a Merit grade for the actual university work.

title.en-GB: Nottingham - BEng in Product Design and Manufacture at The University of Nottingham

excerpt.en-GB: In September 2009 I headed off to Nottingham to study a engineering degree in product design and manufacture. Throughout I ended up designing all sorts of projects, founded my startup, wrote a paper on the future of home design and achieved a first class degree whilst being top of my class.

content.en-GB:
![Nottingham Design Exhibition](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/wShhSFxQd2S2QqSaWy4ws/067988795de6d155c75fba0f44a2a149/nottingham-design-exhibition.jpg) In September 2009 I had finished school and headed off to the University of Nottingham to study and engineering degree in product design and manufacture. A course that is halfway between mechanical engineering and an BA in product design, also known as industrial design. Throughout my 3 years there I had studied modules in the areas of:

*   Engineering mathematics
*   Mechanics
*   Materials and material forming
*   Electromechanical systems
*   Physical and cognitive ergonomics
*   [Sketching](https://charliejackson.com/sketchwork/)
*   Modeling techniques
*   3D/computer Modeling
*   Photoshop, Illustrator, 3Ds Max, Pro Engineer and Google Sketchup
*   Production management
*   Rapid prototyping and modern manufacturing techniques
*   Sustainable manufacture

The best parts of the course lay in the design projects we did as both individual and group work. With these projects we were given briefs from the tutors of from nationwide competitions and would go through the entire design, prototyping and pitching process. During our studio time, the University got in industry experts to help advise us alongside the tutors. Here's a brief run down of some of the projects, most of which I have written about elsewhere on this site:

*   [Nottingham city bus shelter](https://charliejackson.com/busshelter/)
*   Branded car emergency pack
*   [Hostess trolley](https://charliejackson.com/kitchen-block-a-modern-day-hostess-trolley/)
*   3D printed camping cup
*   [Mobile market stall](https://charliejackson.com/marketstall/)
*   [Electronic notepad for "Tomorrow's Workplace"](https://charliejackson.com/e-lectronic-notepad-a-smart-e-paper-notebook/)
*   [A range of wifi, colour changing lights](https://charliejackson.com/lumine/)
*   Baby monitor
*   Hand blender
*   Elastic band powered toy kart
*   Injection moulded mobile phone holder

The main part of my degree was the major project in the last year. This was a 6 month long project, where we got to choose our own problem to try and solve and work on it full time until our final presentation. I decided to look at designing products for the smart home of the future. Which resulted in [Lumine](https://charliejackson.com/lumine/), a range of wifi colour changing lights. ![Lumine overview image](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3b0iszDBzOOuIGkigKkOYQ/9964315f0cf1eadaa1631b4090c0cc70/lumine-overview.jpg) Another big part was the dissertation, for this I looked at the future of home design. This involved a lot of research on the history of art and design, in which I ended up creating a giant pin board timeline to help collect my thoughts and visualise trends. You can read more about my dissertation and the future of home design on [this post](https://charliejackson.com/dissertation/). During my time at Nottingham I also founded my startup Nine Studios. As I new I wanted to work on my own ideas and be part of the startup scene. Initially Nine Studios started as a design consultancy and I worked on a few graphic design projects, building logos and website designs. You can see the full history of Nine Studios and our current work on my [post about it](https://charliejackson.com/nine-studios-my-tech-startup/). ![Nine Studios Mood Board](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4xdSknSLjyGEq6yAWaSwAy/d6609b5cf0da610b3d3f8f6422e3f570/nine-studios-mood-board.jpg) In the end I achieved a 1st class degree with honours and graduated top of my class in 2012\. Turns out working hard paid off. ![Charlie Jackson Graduation Pic](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3SRzFMKqsEgqaWUSWKyQwe/4a485cdcfe823f665f85b5594c236957/charlie-jackson-graduation.jpg)

title.en-GB: Graftt - Working as the Design Officer

excerpt.en-GB: In September 2014 I joined the small startup Graftt as the Design Officer. Based in a warehouse around Shoreditch, it had the classic east London tech startup vibe. At the time Graftt was an agency that developed internet of things (IoT) products and consulted in design and technology.

content.en-GB:
![Graftt Banner](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4P6DzOkB3aOiAEOG8YaAkm/76412ad2a018e2de15517895d2ad1564/graftt-banner.jpg)

> "Graftt is an innovation and invention company. We help organisations design and build new products, services and experiences."

In September 2014 I joined the small startup Graftt as the Design Officer. Based in a warehouse around Shoreditch, it had the classic east London tech startup vibe. At the time Graftt was an agency that developed internet of things (IoT) products and consulted in design and technology. When I joined was a team of 3; myself, the founder and chief strategist and an experienced designer. During my time there I was involved in several projects:

*   [DataLight](https://charliejackson.com/datalight/) - A connected light for the workplace that uses light to represent business data
*   [Product Stories](https://charliejackson.com/productstories/) - A video and audio podcast in which we interviewed entrepreneurs about how they built their products
*   Graftt website - Our home for telling the world about our services
*   [TalkLab website](https://charliejackson.com/talklab/) - A website we built for the non profit organisation TalkLab
*   Pitch support - Doing the research, support work and participating in client brainstorms for dozens of client pitches
*   Blog posts - Keeping the Graftt blog populated with compelling content

I learned loads from working as Graftt, as it was one of my first jobs not working for my own startup. Primarily my professional skills, team skills and attention to detail vastly increased. This was also the time that I started getting heavily into programming and electronics, having built several websites and spent a lot of time programming Raspberry Pi's. My writing style also improved greatly, as I was encouraged to read and make use of the ideas in the [Pyramid Principle](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Pyramid-Principle-Logic-Writing-Thinking/dp/0273710516), a fantastic book about conveying ideas in the most efficient way possible. One of the skills I developed towards the end of my time at Graftt was my camera, film and video editing skills. As we produced a video and audio podcast, [Product Stories](https://charliejackson.com/productstories/), where our founder would interview entrepreneurs about how they built their products. During this I was solely responsible for all the recording and editing, which was a great way of getting better and having something great to show for it. I left Graftt in March 2015 when we ran out of money. Here is the official intro to Graftt for anyone who is particularly interested:

> "We are a Strategic Design Consultancy that creates products, services and experiences using understanding and technology to bring meaningful change to the world. To do this we build interdisciplinary project teams that take a research-led approach and work outwards from the customer. Our processes are always lean, meaning a strong focus on prototyping and experiential development. And we practise what we preach – so we will always be starting new ventures that feed back into our consultancy work. Structurally, we are a combination of three different organisational models – part-design agency, part-management consultancy and part-technology startup. We chose this hybrid structure as it allows us to meet the challenges of our clients with flexibility and resilience. It is a reflection of our belief that to bring new things into the world, we must begin work way before a brief has been created and finish long after a prototype has been delivered. And why are we called Graftt? Well, graft means “hard work” in Northern English slang. We believe that all great things come from hard work, and that they take time, effort and focus."

title.en-GB: Brentwood School - 11-18 Year Old Charlie Gets an Education

excerpt.en-GB: From 2002 - 2009 I attended Brentwood School in Essex for my secondary level education. This was a crazy time of transformation from the geeky little boy in green glasses doing magic, to the much more geeky maths, physics and design teenager who was in the Big Band and house prefect.

content.en-GB:
![Brentwood School](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/12J5809bRioy8YGcQY2GQm/bd0cc2e525f4314bd9b97e7d5b0817d1/brentwood-school.jpg) From 2002 - 2009 I attended Brentwood School in Essex for my secondary level education. This was a crazy time of transformation from the geeky little boy in green glasses doing magic, to the much more geeky maths, physics and design teenager who was in the Big Band and house prefect. Luckily though it was interspersed with moments of detentions, being suspended for calling a teacher ugly during a fire drill, being on the rugby and tennis teams and messing about on Spanish and German trips. What follows is a brief run down of the various things that happened at Brentwood:

## A Levels

In 2007 I started my A-levels, and for some reason had decided to do further mathematics, physics and product design. After the first year in the lower 6th I had already got an A grade in the entire maths A Level and decided to stop doing the further maths bit during the upper 6th. This meant I only did 2 subjects in my last year, physics and product design, whilst still getting 3 A levels, which is all a university wanted. I feel like I cheated the system, as everyone else still had 3 subjects in the last year and still got the same amount of A levels as me. So much free time! Mwuhahahahaha. I ended up finishing Brentwood with the following A Levels:

*   Maths - A
*   Product Design - A
*   Physics - B

## GCSE's

GCSE's were a fairly dull affair in general. We had no free periods during this time and were forced to do exams in all sorts of subjects you didn't care about at the time. I did the exams between 2006 and 2007 with the following results:

*   Mathematics - A*
*   Double Science - A*, A*
*   Spanish - A*
*   Systems and Control (Electronics) - A*
*   Religious Education - A*
*   Geography - A*
*   Art - A
*   English Language - A
*   English Literature - B

## Product Design

Product design and electronics were 2 of my favourites subjects at school. Which I guess makes sense seeing as I went on to do [BEng in Product Design and Manufacture at the University of Nottingham](https://charliejackson.com/nottingham/). During this time I ended up doing:

*   Designing and building a modular desk system
*   Built a waterproof speaker specifically for mounting on sailing dinghies
*   Made a working portable audio mixer
*   Won the gold award for the nationwide Engineering Education Scheme
*   Was on the winning Team of the May Gurney Technology Competition
*   Got the Brentwood School Technology prize in my final year

![Desk Design](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/6nFh4FG8DYguSCuW4EOyOU/b860367538852cdfe25440d9fe7d5250/desk-design.jpg)

## Music

When I started at Brentwood I decided to learn the saxophone, probably because I liked the way it sounded on the Simpsons. I ended up with weekly lessons at school and worked my way up to Jazz grade 5, and was working on grade 8 just before I left. I had also joined the school's Big Band, which regular performed to audiences of up to a few hundred people. The best part about being in the big band was getting to go on the music trip to Nuremberg in Germany. Where we were all excited as 16 year olds on a school trip but we could legally drink alcohol! Things got very messy and I'm sure we didn't play to our best ability when it came to the performances :s ![Saxophone](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/Ml1JRvUe2W0oUeII2KaQy/6769b0b333edf858b31bf33cc2bd2aa6/saxophone.jpg)

## Sport

I was in the school tennis and rugby teams throughout my time at Brentwood. I ended up being the first seed in my year at tennis, both in singles and doubles, representing the school in numerous matches.  Tennis became my main focus towards my latter years at Brentwood, as I was working part time as a tennis coach at the time, so it took most of my focus. Rugby I just did for a bit of banter, played fly half and did all the kicking and bossing the backs around. ![Rugby](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/NKIqaRxb4iGEwayAosg0u/f82fb5f87deaa4d23d3e41c944b95d5b/rugby.jpg)

## Viki

School is where I met my now wife [Viki Bell](https://vikibell.com). One of the main reasons I chose to go to Brentwood in the first place was because it was the best mixed school I could get into. And I ended up having to travel about an hour on the school bus to and from school everyday because of this choice. However it all played out well in the end, as I started going out with Viki when we were 15\. This made it much easier to get to school, as she lived super close by, so if I stayed over I could get a lie in :)

## Misc

Other more minor points of note include:

*   Being part of the CCF (schools armed forces), in the Navy branch and having to do drills and things every Friday. Best part was not having to where school uniform on Fridays, although the army uniform did make us look like twats
*   The Spanish exchange trips were always good fun, and I can still scrounge by in Spanish speaking countries, but not as well as I use to
*   Ended up going through the wall of our 6th form common room after jumping on a friends back and playing rodeo
*   Accidentally pulling down a friends trousers and pants in front of the head of 6th form, still not sure how I didn't get a detention or something for that

title.en-GB: Tip and Turn - Caping Cup Design Focussing on Manufacturability

excerpt.en-GB: This was a small design project whilst I was studying in Nottingham. A camping cup that had to be injection moulded in 3 or less parts and provide superior stability in unusual and rough situations.

content.en-GB: ![Tip and Turn](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4bNYdqHJR6GEI8AGGAEAqU/bde66056d154b3c0378ebe432a63a45e/tip-and-turn.jpg) At the start of my last year studying design, I was given a 3 week individual project to design a camping cup. The cup was to have superior stability for unusual and rough situations. The main focus of this project however was the manufacturability of it. It had to be designed out of 3 or less parts and be injection moulded on a specific type of machine. We were asked to consider all the limitations of the process and to create detailed engineering drawings of the product. This project was a really good insight into the amount of technical problems and considerations which are involved in creating a real world product. I was very insistent on having a specifically curved shaped for the main section. Even though this would have a big undercut problem if it was to be made out of one part. I explored various ways of producing this and settled on 2 parts which would be ultrasonic welded together, to escape this problem. I created a rapid prototype model of my product which really helped to prove I had the right dimensions and shape. The final design is a cup where the lid can be screwed on the top or bottom to add extra stability. All the parts are made out of ABS and I included a simple diagram of how the mould would come apart from the larger section. As it is not always apparent and proves the principle. The mould has different surface finishes to create a textured surface under the curved feature which adds a little defining detail to the design. ![Tip and Turn Manufacture](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1rlMxodAakgK8icqgygA4/9ed1688062acfcd31d66aa18b0fcd107/tip-and-turn-manufacture.jpg) ![Tip and Turn](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4N5qw2OX1SuaK4yS6uQQAu/5d9e0a82b3e68cd3e13929ae58e252c6/tip-and-turn.jpg) ![Tip and turn Dimensions](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5zhHqsjWyAmyUACYwqSuYs/66f5df0c715a11b3ef15129003acaf7a/tip-and-turn-dimensions.jpg)

title.en-GB: Car Emergency Pack - Branding and Design Project

excerpt.en-GB: The brief for this 3 week project was to design a car emergency pack which consisted of a case, a pair of scissors, a torch and a medical pack. We were to create a mood board for particular car brand and directly apply aspects of the board to our designs.

content.en-GB: ![Car Emergency Pack](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4Jk9dV7Iw0mg8skk0iw4gW/45fae5cedd0a7c02d9f2cbd9d9b8cae2/car-emergency-pack.png) The brief for this 3 week project was to design a car emergency pack which consisted of a case, a pair of scissors, a torch and a medical pack. We were to create a mood board for  particular car brand and directly apply aspects of the board to our designs. The whole project was about branding and making parts feel like a set. I chose Toyota as my brand and went to work studying their brand principles and analysing their products.  From this I created the following mood board. ![Toyota Mood Board](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/15WY5dm7hoAiEssigwMY2I/807fd003707299759fd381fd137f6eb3/toyota-mood-board.png) When it came to the designs, I took particular notice of the way the curves end and overhang other elements. This feature seemed quite consistent amongst the brand. I also liked the blue colour of the board and the black and metallic feel you can get from the image. I took these principles and created several concepts. My final design shown here applies these principles in a simple and elegant manner. We were also marked on the manufacturing feasibility of the product and the exploded view below, helps to show how the parts could be moulded and would fit together. This project was the first time I used Pro Engineer and 3DS Max to design and render one of my own designs. These images became and important part of my final display boards. ![Car Emergency Pack Explode View](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/fV8cC72IRqkGeuQ0WkSK2/0780c8cadef63474cebf589dceb4e37b/car-emergency-pack-explode-view.png) ![Car Emergency Pack Dimensions](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3EL61P78msm08eWywCKSCM/452286b54ef74c5512618d2d4cac2ad3/car-emergency-pack-dimensions.png)

title.en-GB: Cocoon - Baby Monitor Design

excerpt.en-GB: This was a 3 week project I did whilst studying product design at Nottingham. We were given a brief to design a baby monitor with a focus on the use of semantics to inspire the form of the product. We were given the required functions and electronics so most of our focus was on form and manufacturing.

content.en-GB: This was a 3 week project I did whilst studying product design at Nottingham. We were given a brief to design a baby monitor with a focus on the use of semantics to inspire the form of the product. We were given the required functions and electronics so most of our focus was on form and manufacturing. I looked at what a baby monitor means to a parent. From this I started sketching around these words and principles. I particularly liked the idea of a cocoon shape as it symbolises comfort, growth and protection, in an aesthetically pleasing form. ![Cocoon Mood Board](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3OvYn1AKLKIkgSKa6q0S0I/4431777ddd1ec924c9fd3f684ef38ef9/cocoon-mood-board.jpg) I took this design and played around with the different shapes I could have, using clay models to further experiment. With my ideal solution I went through the technical details needed to injection mould the component in ABS. We were required to submit engineering drawings of all the parts and show what standard components we had used. ![Cocoon Assembly](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/41Rlf0IKZy2Mgg6ms22qoE/b917aadd8080c8888789535613df1a33/cocoon-assembly.jpg) My final design has an injection moulded cocoon structure with a rotating top to turn the product on and off. The assembly is then tightly wrapped and bonded in leather, which acts to show the wrapping and protecting nature of the product. All of these design aspects helps to subtly symbolise the semantic nature of my design.   ![Cocoon - Baby Monitor](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5qHDTSwz4s62sQ4ESiaAaK/a473b2f12433fe05fb7543d67261ecb8/cocoon-baby-monitor.jpg)

title.en-GB: Desk Design - A Level Design Project

excerpt.en-GB: This was my A level design project whilst still at school. I designed and built a modular and flexible desk system for a more efficient workplace.

content.en-GB: ![Desk Model](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/3Bl6owz2g8IcuOiW4Y2iqm/d6d95fbd97691e5dd925bfd9e78fd71f/desk-model.jpg) For my A level design project I was able to choose any problem I wanted to. I've always been insistent on reorganising and changing my workplace to get the most efficient use of space for the specific task I was doing. Taking this I gave myself the problem of creating an easily flexible and efficient workspace. My final design involved a desk system where you could add on separate modules, like levels, drawers and pull out sections. I created mini wooden prototypes to test out joining methods for the parts and modules. From these I took my first steps in CAD software and played around with Google Sketch Up until I could model and animate my design concept to figure out real world dimensions and fixings. ![Desk Explosion](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1DuduIszjmUYK0yuU4OgOM/7945ee0484e1766111e0edc534ebf139/desk-explosion.jpg) Being primarily a woodwork project this time I got the chance to play around with even more manufacturing techniques and different mechanical fixings. I really liked the way you could put in a lot of care and attention into the model in order to make it look and feel the best it could. To me, I was amazed that I had created something that felt like a real product and could actually use at home. This project helped me get an  A grade for my Product Design A Level. ![Desk Layout](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/328qqD2wacEW8eOIw6uyY4/5f35dea09cb70f1e3d2432673d5ce3c4/desk-layout.jpg) ![Desk Layout](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/69dNIqkOyWOm04YaAmwSmI/471f55afb17613fb6ee20bf99fe6eaf1/desk-layout.jpg) ![Desk Layout](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5jEdXXjpSo8GucOaA0Si4I/158810deb193c8a6ace509cf5d838f07/desk-layout.jpg) ![Desk Mini Model](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1Xz5Y9dnCUyykCgE6kOO0k/56503a1706f607cae6122b1e442989ae/desk-mini-model.jpg) ![Desk Mini Model](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/Eq17JBpfAy0Gms6YaIwCo/1e57e5960cc9998d1b2a5f64aed8b66c/desk-mini-model.jpg) ![Desk Model Workshop](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/6rcCA5r516sCuOkmA4s4ou/16ab9747645da1dc31e0e1978b1cefe4/desk-model-workshop.jpg)

title.en-GB: Sailing Sound System - AS Level Design Project

excerpt.en-GB: This project was my major piece of course work during my product design AS level. I got to choose my own problem and being a keen sailor I decided to tackle the problem of having an easily portable way of playing music on small dinghies.

content.en-GB: ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/VFKhIZOtUW0kOUMqiuequ/7a5f1e34433801c7b66aa68dfc3a1146/sailing-sound-system.jpg) This project was my major piece of course work during my product design AS level. I got to choose my own problem and being a keen sailor I decided to tackle the problem of having an easily portable way of playing music on small dinghies. The course was very practically orientated and was a very good introduction for me to see what I could design and make myself in a workshop. Being my first experience in product design I played around with different approaches to design and got hands on making models, very quickly. After my initial designs and models I started work on my final prototype. The basic design is quite simple as shown below. The 2 circular ends hold the speakers behind an aluminium case, rubber seal and screw on lid which helps to allow a tight seal for an MP3 player to be housed. ![Sailing Sound System](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/4pU2coSAzKgQwQGCa8aA26/815d46cc6a4efec6ac59f1b9a59a4e9e/sailing-sound-system.jpg) ![Charlie Jackson Annealing](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/ESlSn19jhIyI0Q2ueaQuE/d76fa65a0432bf4e54f5e0029d569564/charlie-jackson-annealing.jpg)

title.en-GB: Portable Audio Mixer - GCSE Electronics Project

excerpt.en-GB: For my GCSE electronics coursework I decided to make a portable audio mixer that would allow me to use 1 amplifier/loudspeaker for multiple inputs. As I was playing a lot of guitar and recording all sorts of weird stuff at the time. This was a great project to get to grips with some basic electronics and actually make something I could use.

content.en-GB: ![Portable Audio Mixer Use](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1ZBXZIFZ44gWSUq2IS2Awa/f19273d641aca2679bd5198cfcb49c32/portable-audio-mixer-use.jpg) For my GCSE electronics coursework I decided to make a portable audio mixer that would allow me to use 1 amplifier/loudspeaker for multiple inputs. As I was playing a lot of guitar and recording all sorts of weird stuff at the time. This was a great project to get to grips with some basic electronics and actually make something I could use. I made several prototypes, using breadboards and computer software to see if I could effectively mix the signals and get all the resistance right etc. After I made sure I could make the electronics for it, I begun figuring out a casing for everything. Most of the electronics were fixed in place and I built a compartment at the back to easily replace the battery. In the end I had built a product that worked and ended up achieving an A* for my GCSE, winning all round. I also named it the C max 300, because... why not. ![Portable Audio Mixer Inside](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/wiQl2YZJTwGWCAQMQmA2G/78aa5c071e24909fc2bd773c1c0852c6/portable-audio-mixer-inside.jpg) ![Portable Audio Mixer Front](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1PKJg9HWCc28u6UkM4QO2Q/3ce733bdbb79bf355eb9946da824a3f8/portable-audio-mixer-front.jpg) ![Portable Audio Mixer Top](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2SL0PMkEhiAKy4EgssUMSa/cd36b3d739221b0e00c46ea25a45d91a/portable-audio-mixer-top.jpg) ![Portable Audio Mixer Electronics](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/5nIR7khEAwEYeaYomOqUUI/071a4ef59e3f10bfdfbd9cc6ff695e90/portable-audio-mixer-electronics.jpg) ![Portable Audio Mixer Test Top](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/57lq0cXyycGmqM8KygAuoy/46dfdb685b0870f2d4413036c33349ad/portable-audio-mixer-test-top.jpg) ![Portable Audio Mixer Underside](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/1MBTkiiYVi24IiIweomga/93fbbe9ed34f9cff35f8060abafd978c/portable-audio-mixer-underside.jpg)

title.en-GB: Yeoman - Programming Templates

excerpt.en-GB: In an effort to maintain and improve the quality of my code and the ease at which I can set up a new project I have been setting up Yeoman templates for as many project setups that I can. I want these templates to be my master versions of the way I should be programming. So I can look back at them and update them when I learn new bits and pieces.

content.en-GB:
In an effort to maintain and improve the quality of my code and the ease at which I can set up a new project I have been setting up Yeoman templates for as many project setups that I can. I want these templates to be my master versions of the way I should be programming. So I can look back at them and update them when I learn new bits and pieces. Here are some of the ones I have started on:

*   [Eslint](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-eslint) - Containing my current Javascript linting preferences
*   [Generator](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-generator) - A generator for creating generators
*   [Gitignore](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-gitignore) - Creates a standard gitignore file for various project types
*   [Editor Config](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-editor-config) - My current default .editorconfig file
*   [Cucumber JS](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-cucumber-js) - Adding cucumber testing to your project
*   [Git](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-git) - Setting up git and gitflow for a project
*   [package.json](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-package-json) - Extended version of 'npm init'
*   [React JS](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-react-js) - Containing various configs for setting up ReactJS in a project
*   [Backup](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-backup) - For setting up different backing up systems for projects
*   [Docker](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-docker) - Sets up common Docker commands
*   [Jest](https://github.com/cajacko/generator-jest) - For adding the Jest Javascript testing to your project

You should be able to see an updated list here on [Github](https://github.com/cajacko?utf8=%E2%9C%93&tab=repositories&q=generator&type=&language=), in case I forget to come back and edit this list.

title.en-GB: Renders - Photo Realistic Rendering

excerpt.en-GB: Over the years doing product design I've had to present and pitch my ideas all the time. A lot of these times have involved creating computer made renders of my designs to help convey what a product might look like to people who aren't as familiar with looking at sketches. Here I have pulled together a collection of renders I have done throughout my work, startup and education.

content.en-GB: ![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/65OIAggVS80kKwOOO82Kck/97c59165391e13c5177e2e8fe6664d6a/rendershaver.jpg) Over the years doing product design I've had to present and pitch my ideas all the time. A lot of these times have involved creating computer made renders of my designs to help convey what a product might look like to people who aren't as familiar with looking at sketches. Here I have pulled together a collection of renders I have done throughout my work, startup and education. Most of the renders would have used a combination of Pro Engineer, 3DS Max and Photoshop. title.en-GB: Nine Store

content.en-GB:
![](//images.contentful.com/1gvc9x9hfuhs/2pJB2936JuEccuAuKsq0Q4/33bcf3ed0d42e10b416cd26854fd8fd9/nine-store.png) Nine store was the main focus of my start up between September 2012 and February 2013\. We built an online store that sold smart home products. The main selling point was the works with section and the product recommendations. As many smart home products work better when used together I wanted to helped consumers see this and see what would work in their homes and with their current devices. As this seemed the biggest adoption barrier to people using smart home products. Throughout this project I was studying a [masters degree in technology entrepreneurship](https://charliejackson.com/ucl/). The course helped me to develop the business model, where our future plans would be to have other sections of the company that would build smart home products that integrates well with others and that we could sell through our store. We also built a prototype website, built with Wordpress we added dozens of smart home products. Showing consumers what products work with each other and using Amazon affiliate links to track any purchases through Amazon. This approach meant we could easily build something to test the market without needing to store and ship products ourselves. Throughout developing this business we could not generate the traffic or interest needed to justify developing it further. Also I missed not building our own products. This is when nine studios dropped nine store and begun work building [Photine](https://charliejackson.com/photine/). A smarter range of digital photo frames.
